author: muesliswap
title: Bridgeless atomic cross chain swaps
description: In order to transfer assets between Cardano and other blockchains, one needs a lot of steps involving an intermediary, which limits the accessibility of the Cardano ecosystem by the general public.

f6_assessments.q0: The proposal effectively addresses the challenge. Very easy interaction between blockchains, without a bridge and the associated loss of UX, absolutetly fits the cross-chain collaboration challenge.

f6_assessments.q0:
Moving value from one chain to another is always a pain in the neck. Bridges exist but they can be cumbersome to use and many of them have been proven unsecure. The MuesliSwap team proposes a small research and development effort into the possibility of using atomic swaps for cross-chain value transfer.

The reason this was not submitted to the Great Migration challenge is probably the fact that the same logic can be then applied to any chain. Mind you, even the Plutus and EVM implementation should be usable outside of Ethereum in EVM-supported chains like Avalanche, Moonbeam or Acala, for instance.

Consequently, I fully agree that this proposal can have a significant impact in making Cardano interoperable with other chains. It goes above and beyond what is expected in the challenge and contributes to the Fund9 goals of open-sourcing Cardano and improving the Developer ecosystem.
f6_assessments.q1:
The MuesliSwap team (https://www.openswap.tech/) took everyone by surprise, being the first DEX on Cardano and appearing only with their first names in the beginning. They were doubted and criticized but, once people tried their service, the naysayers soon disappeared. After that they have come to public with their full names and faces, and they have proven what they are capable of. Hence, what they are proposing here is most likely to be another success. They have an amazing capacity of explaining somewhat technical solutions in layman terms.

It is possible, however, that their proposed solution doesn't work. Right now their understanding of atomic cross-chain swaps between Plutus and EVM-supported chains is based on existing research but no one has tried this in practice. It could fail. That’s why they are only aiming for a proof of concept with a small budget of $25,000. It’s a small price to pay for this experiment because the potential upside is immense. If nothing else, the Cardano developers’ community will learn the limitations of this approach. They can then iterate and innovate around it. If it does work, the MuesliSwap team will cover the development costs of the actual product.
f6_assessments.q2:
The team’s solution matches the given problem statement very well. Deliverables are: 1) formal description of cross-chain trading protocol (paper), 2) security analysis, and 3) reference implementation deployed on testnet.

They will measure the completion of said deliverables and report to the community. Code produced will be open source and made available to anyone in a GitHub repository.

f6_assessments.q0: The proposal aims to provide a bridgeless atomic swaps – swaps that will allow transferring assets between Cardano blockchain and another blockchains without having intermediary, and thus reducing the complexity of such transfer. This solution would make wrapped tokens redundant and would make swapping assets way easier. The solution itself will be a combination of signatures and timelocks – what does it mean? It means that if someone would like to trade e.g. ETH for ADA, and such order is placed on each of chains (e.g. ETH sell for ADA on ETH chain). Once such order is created, the creator will become market maker – thus, the order will be there unless someone matches the offer exactly. Once that happens, assets are locked on each trading side, then confirmation of this lock will happen inside the protocol and traders will be asked for signing. Once signed – both assets are swapped, or the trade is completely reversed. I think that such protocol could eventually speed up cross chain collaboration and eventually make the whole transaction process easier. It is important to state, that this proposal is actually proof of concept of the solution, between plutus and EVM, thus much is not clear yet. But overall, the idea is very good. ´
f6_assessments.q1: The budget asked is 25 000 USD in total, and the roadmap is not set. I have checked the planned activities and the total hours planned is set to 300 hours, which is 37,5 Full time for one dev. To improve the feasibility section, the roadmap (or estimated time frame – e.g. 3 months) could have been provided, as well as how many people will actually be developing the protocol. The budget is calculated based on expected hours, but hourly wages vary in respect to the task planned. Example – 180 hours for R&D, for 12 k USD = 66 USD/hour, comparing to Reference implementation 120 hours for 6 k USD = 50 USD. Another information that I am missing is with respect to the team – I am quite familiar with MuesliSwap, but it would be beneficial for those who are not (not all voters can be familiar with MuesliSwap) and some representative should be introduced, if not the whole team (if it is already settled).
f6_assessments.q2: The problem (to complex cross chain assets trade) and the solution (protocol that will make it easier) is clear, and the deliverable will be to create such protocol. The protocol itself will be open-sourced, so we are able to track the progress. Also, the team stated that it will be possible to track the progress with the respect to deliverables which are mentioned in the feasibility section, but without the clear roadmap, I think it will be quite hard. I believe that success of the proposal will be once all deliverables are finished, but I think that team should have added metrics that would actually provide a picture, whether the protocol is being used or no, e.g. number of trades performed using this protocol. At the same time, there is no reference for any public channel, so just a note for proposer – make sure you keep the track of the progress on discord/telegaram or twitter, so the community is able to audit the progress, or the success eventually.

solution: We aim to create a scalable protocol that can be used to trade assets between Cardano and other blockchains, not based on a bridge. This can be realized in multiple variants of so-called atomic swaps.
experience: We are OpenSwap Technologies - the team behind MuesliSwap, one of the biggest dApps on Cardano. As developers of DeFi infrastructure, we have experience with all relevant aspects of off-chain & on-chain code, haskell programming, and security of smart contracts.
